title: ‘Stolen: Heist of the Century’ Review: Netflix’s Diamond in a Spare Setting
description: Directed by Mark Lewis, this bare-bones but engaging documentary follows the aftermath of the 2003 Antwerp diamond robbery, offering frank commentary from the investigators.
content:
The official loss figure attached to the subject of “Stolen: Heist of the Century” was $100 million in U.S. dollars, though Agim De Bruycker , former commander of Belgium’s “diamond squad,” says, “I am absolutely sure the figure was much higher.” Or, these days, lower: The rise of synthetic gems and their undermining of the traditional market might now place the infamous 2003 Antwerp diamond robbery in a much less glamorous category of caper. But “Stolen” is a period piece, as well as a police procedural.

It is, also, a curiously engaging, bare-bones documentary, adapted by director Mark Lewis from the book “Flawless” by Scott Andrew Selby and Greg Campbell . Its charms actually lie in its lack of embellishment and in straightforward storytelling. While there is a variety of atmospheric editing and scene-setting visuals, almost the entire account is told through the recollections of a handful of people, principally Mr. De Bruycker and fellow detective Patrick Peys . The crime occurred long enough ago that no one then involved is afraid of talking now, especially Leonardo Notarbartolo , a Sicilian career criminal who claims not to have been the mastermind of the crime, but was eventually sentenced to 10 years in prison.
summary: Netflix's "Stolen: Heist of the Century" is a period piece and police procedural about the 2003 Antwerp diamond robbery in which the official loss figure for the crime was $100 million in U.S. dollars, though Agim De Bruycker, former commander of Belgium's "diamond squad," believes the figure was significantly higher. The documentary, adapted by director Mark Lewis from the book "Flawless," is praised for its straightforward storytelling and lack of embellishment. The account is told through the recollections of several individuals, including De Brukycker and fellow detective Patrick Peys. Leonardo Notarbartolo, a Sicilian career criminal who claims not to have been the mastermind of the crime, was sentenced to 10 years in prison.
shortSummary: "Stolen: Heist of the Century” is a straightforward, understated documentary about the 2003 Antwerp diamond heist, featuring interviews and visuals from various angles.

Directed by Mark Lewis and based on the book "Flawless," the film presents a straightforward narrative primarily through the accounts of key figures involved, including former detective Agim De Bruycker and criminal Leonardo Notarbartolo. The film's charm lies in its lack of embellishment and engaging storytelling, set against the backdrop of a changing diamond market influenced by synthetic gems.
